page.title: 18SUPERSTITION IN THRESHFIELD
page.content: Of the many{superstitions}the story of {'Pam the Fiddler'}is the most local. {'Pam'}is the ghost of a former {Threshfield Schoolmaster}who was murdered by the{Rector}because he regarded the playing of such an instrument as unbecoming of a{master of{Threshfield School. 'Pam'}(the reason for such a name is unknown) is said to appear as a figure dressed in {Schoolmasters clothing}with the {bearded head}of a{goat.}He is said to haunt the{Primary School. One famous incident goes as follows: A{Girston Tinker}was passing the {school}on a cold night and was attacked by{'Pam'.}The{Tinker took refuge in{'Holy Well'.}Because of this {'Pam'}was unable to put a spell on him but thought that the{'Tinker '}would die of cold anyway.However, the{Tinker eventually emerged feeling fitter.
